item.title: Ucertify AWS SysOps Certification review
item.description: Preamble - about myself For those who don’t know me, I come from a extreme Sysop background. For more than ten years, I’ve strayed away of the developer world problems, focusing on automation of regular infrastructure and other user-directed services. For the last years, though, I’ve been thrown on the eye of the hurricane that is the new agile aplication deployment and Devops world - thus becoming the senior sysadmin of the most insane, multipurpose Kubernetes-as-a-PaaS solution ever developed.

item.title: AWS S3: creating bucket policy
item.description: Task at hand: create a bucket policy that makes an entire bucket public. Resources used: AWS S3, custom domain registered. So I created a website and hosted it on AWS S3. It worked just as advertised, which is nice, even though it could use a ‘press one button and be done with it’ just as their one-click-shop. As noticed, I had to Grant public read access to all objects on upload.

item.title: AWS S3: Hosting an static Website
item.description: Task at hand: host a static website on a S3 bucket. URL for the website will be: yellatcloud.devsres.com Resources used: AWS S3, custom domain registered. Two of the most repeated sentences on the Linkedin Learning AWS Courses I’ve met are: AWS S3 (the object storage service) - is the most widely used Amazon service ever; One can host static websites on AWS S3 trivially. Is that so? Let’s check.

item.title: AWS S3: using Cloudfront for HTTPS
item.description: Task at hand: implement HTTPS to a static website hosted on S3 Resources used: AWS S3, AWS CloudFront So I created a website and hosted it on AWS S3. But no HTTPS! That’s so old-fashioned. Cloudfront Work in Progress! Reference: AWS Cloudfront.
